awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Detecting and Designing Topological Orders in Frustrated Magnets
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports theoretical research and education towards developing new ideas to detect and design topological orders in quantum magnetic materials. Topological orders are exotic phases of quantum systems, in which ordinary electrons behave as if they were divided into smaller particles that contain fractions of the original mass and charge. These emerging particles are called anyons, and due to their quantum properties they could be used in implementing quantum computation. One example of topological order is the so-called quantum spin liquid, a nonmagnetic phase of matter that can emerge in systems of interacting quantum magnets. While topological orders are highly desirable for their potential applications, there are two longstanding obstacles in achieving control of anyons: (i) anyons in topological orders are hard to detect; (ii) topological orders are quite rare in nature to begin with.

This project aims at filling those two gaps in the context of quantum spin liquids. The PI will exploit magnetic impurities that are ubiquitous in real materials to identify a "smoking gun" signature for the detection of anyons in a quantum spin liquid. The PI will also identify new guiding principles to search for realistic models of and materials hosting quantum spin liquids, by building a road map between rare quantum spin liquids and abundant magnetic orders in nature. These research efforts not only bring new ideas for the detection and realization of topological orders, but also shed new light on impurity physics in various quantum magnetic materials.
 
This award also supports educational and outreach efforts that are integrated with the research. In addition to mentoring graduate students and developing modern courses synergistically with the research activities, the PI will also mentor master's degree students from underrepresented groups, involving them in cutting-edge research. Outreach activities will include constructing an interactive website about the PI's research, and educating underrepresented K-5 level students in high-poverty elementary schools with demonstration-based lectures.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports theoretical research and education towards detecting and designing quantum spin liquid phases in frustrated magnetic systems. Quantum spin liquids are exotic ground states of frustrated magnets, which evade all symmetry-breaking orders down to zero temperature. They can support topological orders featuring fractionalized excitations (anyons), which could become building blocks for fault-tolerant topological quantum computation. Though highly desirable, the experimental detection of anyons in quantum spin liquids has been a longstanding challenge. Moreover, the rarity of quantum spin liquids in nature calls for new design principles. 

This project will address these two significant issues. The PI will address the detection issue by answering the following question: is there a "smoking gun" signature of anyons in quantum spin liquids? Magnetic impurities will be explored as a means to provide sharp signatures of anyons, which could subsequently be probed by thermodynamic and spectroscopic measurements in real materials. The effects of magnetic impurities in quantum spin liquids will be investigated by a synergy between analytical effort, numerical simulation, and exact solutions from idealized models. 

The PI will also address the design issue by constructing new models that host quantum spin liquid ground states. This will be achieved by combining an algebraic classification of symmetry-breaking orders in proximity to quantum spin liquids with unbiased numerical simulations. New classes of quantum criticality between a quantum spin liquid and proximate symmetry-breaking phases will also be investigated. 

This award also supports educational and outreach efforts that are integrated with the research. In addition to mentoring graduate students and developing modern courses synergistically with the research activities, the PI will also mentor master's degree students from underrepresented groups, involving them in cutting-edge research. Outreach activities will include constructing an interactive website about the PI's research, and educating underrepresented K-5 level students in high-poverty elementary schools with demonstration-based lectures.

por.por_cntn:
This career award supported a broad range of fundament research and educational programs that focused on the understanding of strongly correlated topological phases and unconventional phase transitions. 

The main research outcomes of this award include:

  • A nonlocal entanglement entropy that can differentiate fracton topological phases to TQFT-type topological orders. 
  • The classification of U(1) spin liquids on the hyperkagome lattice and its implication to pressurized iridates. 
  • Identification of topological in-gap states at the step edge on the (001) surface of topological crystalline insulator Pb0.7Sn0.3Se.
  • Classification of higher-order symmetry protected topological phases in strongly interacting bosonic systems with both crystallien and onsite symmetries
  • A theory proposal to realize chiral hinge modes in magnetic axion insulator Bi2–xSmxSe3
  • A theory proposal to realize high-temperature Majorana corner modes in a 2d topological insulator proximitized by iron-based superconductors. 
  • The new quantum informational concept of "information convex", which can be used to characterize bulk and boundary excitations of a topological order. 
  • Identification of a chiral spin liquid with spinon fermi surfaces in extended Heisenberg models on the triangular lattice.
  • Identification of topological Dirac magnons in room-temperature kagome magnet YMn6Sn6
  • Elucidating the effects of spin orbit couplings on the quantum Hall states in graphen/WSe2 heterobilayers
  • Theoretical discovery of a large family of new Lieb-Schultz-Mattis(LSM)-type theorems for symmetry protected topological (SPT) phases. 
  • Unconventional quantum phase transitions in a model of the aforementioned LSM-SPT system. 
  • Mathematical theory for a large family of phase transitions, where spontaneous symmetry breaking always accompanies the anyon condensation. 
  • Enlarged emergent symmetry at the critical point of spontaneous symmetry breaking induced by anyon condensation, revealed by both theoretical analysis and numerical studies of a 2d model. 
  • Scaling laws of entanglement negativity at the measurement-induced dynamical phase transition in random unitary circuits. 

Among these findings we highlight the following achievements in the theory of topological phases and phase transitions:

1)  We proposed new physical quantities, closely related to entanglement and quantum information, to characterize different intrinsic topolgoical phases. In a Physical Review B publication, we used a nonlocal entanglement entropy to distinguish the newly discovered fracton topological phases to the TQFT-type topological orders. In another Physical Review B publication, we introduced the "information convex" as a new characterization for the bulk anyons and excitations on the gapped boundaries of a 2d topological order. This work further inspired the recent "entanglement bootstrap" program, which intends to derive universal properties of topological orders from quantum entanglement, with few assumptions. 

2) We discovered a new family of Lieb-Schultz-Mattis (LSM) type theorems for quantum many-body systmes with magnetic space group symmetries, which enforce any uniquely gapped ground state of the system to be a symmetry protected topological (SPT) phase. We coin these the "LSM theorems for SPT phases".  We first introduced them in the context of quantum Hall states with magnetic translational symmetries in two dimensions, in an Annals of Physics publication, and then established a general framework to construct these theorems in any spatial dimension in a SciPost publication. This discovery opened a new window to design and realize SPT phases in strongly correlated systems. 

3) We estalished a mathematical theory for a family of unconventional quantum phase transitions, in a JHEP publication, where anyon condensations will necessarily lead to spontaneous symmetry breaking (SSB). This work not only introduced a large class of phase transitions between different symmetry enriched topological orders, but also provided criteria for SSB to happen at these critical points. We further demonstrated an enlarged emergent symmetry at the critical point, by combining theory analysis and numerical studies on a minimal model based on the toric code. These progress opened the door for a wide range of novel critical points beyond the Landau paradigm. 

The education and outreach achievements supported by this award include:

1) Developments of an outreach course "Fun with shapes" for Scientific Thinkers program aiming for K-1 to K-5 students in high-poverty elementary schools in the Columbus school district. 

2) Mentoring an underrepresented minority student from the APS bridge program through the PhD program. 

3) Developments of lecture notes and materials for an advanced graduate course on "Topological Phenomena in Condensed Matters".
